block.p: INTERNATIONAL A3-A8

Qaddafi Heralds Change In Libya, Within Limits Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader who once banned everything from Western music to teaching English in schools and was condemned by Washington for support of terrorism, spoke of opening Libya to the world. But there are limits of how much the country may change. A3

Rebels' Foe Befriends U.S. Abdul Sattar Buzaigh al-Rishawi, the most outspoken Sunni Arab tribal figure in Iraq fighting on the side of the Shiite-led Iraqi government, is asking for more American support. President Bush is considering whether to provide that help to the sheik and other tribal leaders who are disillusioned with the radical arm of the insurgency. A8

Two soccer players were killed in front of other teammates in Ramadi by gunmen who claimed the players collaborated with a group closely tied to Sheik Abdul Sattar, according to witnesses and the police. In eastern Iraq, the bodies of 16 policemen from the Interior Ministry were found a day after a militant group said it had kidnapped 18 ministry employees. A8

Calls for Australian's Return John Howard, the prime minister of Australia, is under mounting pressure to have David Hicks, an Australian citizen who was charged by the American military with a terrorism-related offense, tried and returned home.
A6
NATIONAL A9-12

Army Secretary Resigns Over Reports on Hospital Army Secretary Francis J. Harvey was forced to resign over the handling of revelations that wounded soldiers were receiving shabby and slow treatment at Walter Reed Army Medical Center.
A1
Weather Hurts Maple Industry Warmer-than-usual winters are causing confusion among maple syrup producers, called sugar makers, and stoking fears for the survival of New England's maple forests.
A1

Bus Crash Kills 6 Students A bus that had been traveling all night, taking an Ohio college baseball team to Florida for a series of games, plunged nearly 30 feet off an overpass in Atlanta, killing six people and critically injuring three more, emergency officials said.
A9

Warhead Design Is Chosen The White House announced the winner of a competition to design the nation's first new nuclear weapon in nearly two decades, and immediately set out to reassure Russia and China that the weapon would pose no threat to either nation.

Emissions Expected to Escalate The Bush administration estimates that the United States' emissions of gases that contribute to global warming will grow nearly as fast through the next decade as they did the previous decade, according to a report.
A1
NEW YORK/REGION B1-5

Novice Art Collectors Find Access is Priceless The frenzied pitch of the art market, which sees records broken at auction almost monthly, has made it harder for newcomers to enter the art collector's world. A1

Spitzer Rebuts Opponents While the leaders of two health care groups watched from the audience of a Manhattan power breakfast, Gov. Eliot Spitzer launched into a rebuttal of the groups' claims made against his proposal to cut health care costs. B1
Beliefs
BUSINESS DAY C1-9
Bush to Promote Ethanol President Bush, hoping to reduce demand for oil, is preparing to sign an agreement with Brazil to promote the use of ethanol throughout Latin America and the Caribbean. A1
Business Digest C2
EDITORIAL A14-15
Editorials: No more denials, please; overkill; locking up the ghost of Congress past; a pattern of normal drought.
Columns: Maureen Dowd, Ann Althouse, Rory Stewart.
Bridge B15 Crossword B10 Obituaries C10 TV Listings B16 Weather D8
